About the concentration game, that is.  The bad news
is that I have totally failed to evolve an ANN that
would play better than a random selector of cards. 
This was with the six card deck, two each of three
kinds.  Hours of evolution would produce an ANN that
was as good as the random card selector, but after
that it would not improve.  This is using the fully
recurrent binary ANN which I think I described
earlier.  I tried various number of neurons up to 40. 
I concluded that this configuration is incapable of
remembering the cards it sees and then recalling that
data and using it.  (more about this below)

The good news is that I have succeeded in
demonstrating that such an ANN can remember what it
sees and act upon it.  I decided to simplify the
concentration game to its simplest possible version. 
Here is what I eventually did:  There is a 4 card
deck, two aces and two deuces.  The ANN goes second. 
The first player chooses the first card at random, but
the second card is chosen NOT to match the first card.
 So the ANN sees two non-matching cards and two face
down cards.  Then the cards are turned face down and
the ANN picks one card.  Then the ANN picks a second
card.  That's it!  If the cards match, the ANN wins. 
Otherwise it loses.

If the ANN had no memory and just picked at random it
would win only 33.3% of the time. This is because,
whichever card is picked first, there remain two cards
that don't match and only one that matches.

If the ANN can remember in what positions the first
player found a non-pair, it could increase its win
percentage to 50% by always picking one previously
picked card and one un-picked card.  This would not
require remember what cards it saw, just where they
were picked.

If the ANN can remember everything, then it can win
every time.  Of course it also has to follow the right
strategy, which is to first pick an un-picked card,
and then choose the matching one from the two that
were exposed.  An ANN that does this every time will
win 100%.

The good news is that I have evolved ANNs that win 95%
of the time!  I have checked this carefully and have
confidence in the result.  The evolution seemed to
stop at about 95%.  I'm not sure why this is, but it
may be that more neurons are required.  The 95% result
was with 40 neurons.  

Since this proves that the ANN can remember a series
of patterns and then act correctly using that data, it
would seem that the six card game could be mastered. 
My hypothesis is that many more neurons are required. 
Perhaps one or two hundred are necessary.  OTOH, my
computational resources and patience probably limit me
to 50 neurons max.  I wonder if there are any
theortical results that would apply to this problem?
